propositions.text: This is a story of lineage: of a sixteen-year-old me searching for my father and his past; and of my father searching for his beloved mentor and his mentor's past.
In the process, we discover that in the end we are both standing on a dark road that leads to history.
This is also a story of survival: of who lived, who died, and why.
As a historian, I have come to understand that not everyone who seeks out history can survive it.
Nor is it only the seeking of history that can endanger us; sometimes history itself, with its shadowy claws, will reach out and take us.
Thirty-six years have passed since then.
I have since lived a relatively tranquil life, my time devoted to research, my travels uneventful.
I have been with students, with friends, or have written histories that had little to do with personal feeling, or with the goings-on in the university where I lived.
For years I have kept most of the personal papers that were relevant to that history, and I have been fortunate to have access to them.
I have woven them in where they seemed to fit, to ensure the flow of the story, though I have had to make up for gaps with my own recollections.
And though I am here merely retelling the story my father first told me, I have made extensive use of his letters, some of them identical in content to his oral accounts.
Apart from quoting these materials almost verbatim, I have tried to recapture and reanimate my fading memories by searching for them, sometimes by revisiting the places themselves.
One of the greatest pleasures of this work has been the interviews—sometimes by letter—with scholars mentioned in the story who are still alive.
Their recollections have filled in invaluable gaps for me.
Furthermore, my text has benefited from exchanges with younger scholars in several fields.
Where necessary, I have called upon imagination, as a last resort.
I have used it with great care.
Only when I have been able to confirm what is very likely, and only when such reliable speculation has woven my materials into their context, have I allowed myself to imagine for my readers.
What I have been unable to explain or motivate, I have respected by leaving it in the silence behind it.
The history in the story, in its more distant reaches, I have researched as diligently as I would any scholarly monograph.
For the modern reader, the religious and territorial conflicts between Islam in the East and Judeo-Christianity in the West, alluded to in the story, should be both familiar and painful.
I have been so greatly helped in the completion of this work that words of gratitude are inadequate, but I must nonetheless thank the following by name.

Dr. Radu Georgescu of the Museum of Archaeology of Bucharest University, Dr. Ivanka Lazarova of the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Dr. Peta Stoichev of the University of Michigan, the tireless staff of the British Library, the librarians at the Lutterworth Press and the Philadelphia Museum, Father Vasko of the Zografou Monastery on Mount Athos, and Dr. Turgut Bora of Istanbul University.
My greatest hope in making this story public is that at least one reader will understand its true meaning: that it is a cry from the heart.
To you, the discerning reader, I pass on my history.
January 15, 2008, Oxford University, England
In 1972, I was sixteen.

My father said I was too young to accompany him on a trip he was taking on behalf of the Foundation, whose headquarters were in Amsterdam, where for a long time I had lived, so much so that I had almost forgotten that I had lived in America as a child.
I had always been a good child, and remained so long after I entered adolescence.

The first thing to say is that I was a motherless child, and my father, who was both father and mother to me, gave me his undivided attention, hiring a succession of governesses and housekeepers for me—he never spared expense in my upbringing, though we lived simply.
Mrs. Clay was the last of these housekeepers.
She was responsible for our house on the Keizersgracht, in the center of the old city.
The lovely house was empty when Father was away.
Whenever Father returned from somewhere on the map hanging on the dining room wall, he carried with him the exotic smell of foreign places, high spirits, and exhaustion.
We had vacations in Paris or Rome, where we assiduously visited the sights my father thought I should know.
But I longed most to visit the places he alone had been, the strange and unknown places I had never seen.
When he was away, my life was school and home, and little else.
My happiest times were when I was alone in my father’s large, elegant study on the first floor.
That evening, I took from the shelves a translated edition of the Kama Sutra, along with an older book and a packet of yellowed letters.
I still cannot today understand how I managed to take them down and become so engrossed in them.
The illustrations in the center of the book gave off an ancient smell, and I discovered that the yellowed letters were personal correspondence.
I knew I shouldn’t look at my father’s or anyone else’s private papers, and I dreaded Mrs. Clay’s appearance at any moment to dust the immaculately clean desk, and I glanced toward the door.
But I lingered by the bookshelves, and could not help but read the first paragraph of the topmost letter, and for only a few minutes.
My dearest, unfortunate heir:
Whoever you are, I am very sorry that you are reading the letter I have had to leave behind.
I am sorry for myself—if this letter has reached you, I must have run into trouble, perhaps died, or worse.
But I am sorry for you, too, my unknown friend.
For if you are reading this letter, it must be that someone needs this evil message.
If you are not my heir in any other sense, you will soon be my heir—I am truly sorry to pass on to you this incredible evil that has been passed to me.
I do not know how this evil came to be passed to me, but I hope to find the truth—perhaps in the course of writing this letter, perhaps in the course of events to come.
December 12, 1913, Trinity College, Oxford
Guilt—and other reasons—prompted me to put the letter back into its envelope that day.
But I could not stop thinking about that letter, that day and many days afterward.
My father had just returned from another diplomatic trip, and I was looking for an opportunity to ask him about the letters, and about the strange book.
I wanted to ask him when he was free, and when we were alone, but he was busy those days, and I hesitated to tell him about what I had found, which was odd.
Later, I asked him to take me on his next trip, the first time I had kept a secret from him, and the first time I had insisted on my own way.
Autumn always came early to the Julian Alps in Slovenia.
It was an old country.
For the first time in my life, I saw the profound face of history as a traveler, and was seized by a great excitement.
Because my story begins in this city, I will call it Emona, its Roman name.
Emona, like other cities like it to its south, had a complex history.
My father and I drove into the center of Emona, crossing a delicate old bridge guarded by two verdigris-patinated bronze dragons, one on each end.
“That is the castle,” my father said, slowing the car on the side of the square, pointing upward into the rain curtain.
“I know you want to see it.”
I did.
I strained my neck until I could see the castle through the wet branches—a crumbling brown tower, perched on a steep hill in the center of the city.
“The fourteenth century,” my father mused, “or the thirteenth?
I am not very knowledgeable about these medieval ruins, so I don’t know which century they belong to.
But we can look it up in a guidebook.
“Can we walk up and look around?”
“When I’m finished with my meeting tomorrow, we can find out.
Those towers look ready to fall down, but who knows.”
He drove into a parking lot near the town hall and, with the courtly grace of a gentleman, helped me out of the car, his hands bony within his leather gloves.
“It’s still a bit early to check into the hotel.
Would you like a cup of hot tea?”
We sat at a table by the window, drinking lemon tea from thick cups, eating sardines on white bread with mayonnaise, and several cakes with fruit cream.
“We’ll stop here,” my father said.
Lately I had come to dislike the way he blew on his tea to cool it, and the way he said, “We’ll stop here.”
He would call a halt when you were just getting into the swing of it, and leave you with an appetite for dinner.
Diplomacy had ruined him.
I thought he would have been happier if he had had a little more joy in living.
“I didn’t expect driving to be so tiring,” my father said, putting down his cup and pointing to the castle, barely visible in the rain.
“We came from there, on the other side of the mountain.
You can see the Alps from the top of the mountain.”
I remembered the snow-capped slopes, and how the mountains seemed to breathe down on the city.
Now, on the far side of the mountain, we were alone.
I hesitated, took a breath.
“Will you tell me a story?”
“A story about the Alps?”
“No,” I said, a strange fear rising in my throat.
“I found something, and I wanted to ask you about it.”
He turned, raising the graying eyebrows above his gray eyes, and looked at me gently.
“In your study,” I said.
“I’m sorry—I was poking around, and I found some letters and a book.
I didn’t read—not much—the letters.
I thought—”
“A book?” he asked idly, his tone still gentle.
He looked only at his cup, finishing the last of his tea.
“They looked—the book was old, and in the middle was an illustration of a dragon.”
He leaned forward, sat still, and then began to tremble.
This strange motion made me instantly alert.
If he was going to tell me a story, it would be very different from the ones he had told me before.
He glanced down at me, looking so gaunt, so sad, that I was startled.
“Are you angry?”
I looked down at my own teacup now.
“No, dear,” he said, and sighed heavily, as if grief had choked him.
When I was a graduate student, my father told me, one spring evening, I was sitting alone in a small carrel in the university library, late at night, surrounded by shelves of books.
Suddenly, I realized that someone had placed a book among my textbooks.
I remembered that I had not seen it on the shelf before me, or anywhere else.

I opened it at random and found myself in the middle, where a large woodcut dragon lay across the two pages, its wings spread, its tail curled, its face menacing, its claws hooked into a banner that bore a single name in Gothic letters: DRACULA.
I recognized the name at once: BÉLA LUGOSI (DRACULA).
But the spelling of the name was odd, and the book looked ancient.
Also, I was a scholar, with a great interest in European history.
Dracula was the honorific title of Vlad Tepes of Wallachia—the Impaler—a ruler of a territory in the Carpathian Mountains, known for his torture of his subjects and prisoners.
I was studying seventeenth-century Amsterdam trade at the time, and could not understand how such a book came to be tucked into my own.
Even more surprising, the thin, ivory-colored pages were blank.
The book had no title page, of course, no date or place of publication, no blank pages at the beginning or end, no maps, no other illustrations, no other markings of any kind.

I looked at it for several minutes, placed it on my desk, and went to the first-floor card catalog, where there was indeed a subject card: “Vlad III (Tepes) of Wallachia, 1431-1476—See also Wallachia, Transylvania, and Dracula.”
I thought I should consult a map first.
Soon I found that Wallachia and Transylvania were ancient territories in what is now Romania.

Among the stack of library cards, I found what seemed to be the only primary material in the library on the subject, a strange little English book translated from some pamphlets of the 1890s about the vampire Dracula.
The original was published in Nuremberg in the 1870s and 1880s.
Nuremberg was mentioned here, and a chill ran through me.
Only a few years before, I had followed the trials of Nazi leaders there very closely.
The title page of this pamphlet had a crude woodcut of a man’s head and shoulders, a thick-necked man with bushy eyebrows over dark eyes, a long beard, and a plumed hat.
Despite the primitive technique of the drawing, it was a vivid likeness.

I knew I should get back to my work, but I could not help myself, and began to read the beginning of one of the little pamphlets, which listed the atrocities committed by Dracula on his subjects and on others.
I snapped the little book shut and returned to my seventeenth-century Amsterdam research, fascinated, and read until midnight.
I had class the next morning.
I felt tired from staying up so late.
After class, I drank two cups of coffee and returned to the library to continue my research.
The old book was still on my desk, and it was now open to the page with the dragon coiled on it.
Seeing it, I was startled, as if in a novel.
I opened the book again, this time more carefully.
The dragon in the center was unmistakably a woodcut, perhaps medieval in style, and the book was well made.
I thought it must be valuable, and perhaps of great personal interest to some scholar, for it was clearly not a library book.
I took it to the front desk and gave it to the librarian.
The next morning, at eight o’clock, I dragged myself to the library, and the book was still on my desk.
I was somewhat annoyed—the librarian must have misunderstood me.
I hastily put the book back on the shelf and went about my business.
Later that afternoon, as I was gathering my papers, I took the strange book down and put it with my articles.
I did not want the book, but Professor Rossi was fond of obscure history.
I found Professor Rossi and reported on my studies over the past few weeks, and he poured me a cup of good coffee into a porcelain mug.
Suddenly I remembered the antique book I had brought with me.
“I brought you an antique, Rossi.
Someone accidentally left a dreadful book on my library seat, and it’s been there for two days, and I thought you might like to look at it.”
“Let me see it.”
He put down his delicate coffee cup and held out his hand for the book I offered him.
Something on the spine made his usually clear face crumple.
“Open it,” I urged him.
His face suddenly became very grave—a dead-looking face, not at all the one I knew.
He turned the book front to back, as I had, but his gravity did not turn to surprise.
“Yes, blank.”
He put the book down on the table.
“No writing.”
“Strange, isn’t it?” I asked, my coffee growing cold in my hand.
“And very old.
The blankness is not because the book is unfinished, but because it is deliberately left blank to set off the dragon in the middle.”
“Yes, yes.
As if the dragon in the middle has swallowed everything around it.”
I said this lightly, but my voice trailed off.
Rossi seemed unable to tear his eyes from the dragon before him.
Later, he closed the book with a decisive thump, stirred his coffee, but did not drink it.
“Where did you get this book?”
“As I just told you, someone accidentally left it on my seat in the library two days ago.
I knew I should have taken it to the rare book room immediately, but I really thought it was a private collection, so I did not.”
“Oh, indeed.”
Rossi looked at me.
“It is indeed someone’s private property.”
“Do you know whose?”
“Yours.”
“No, I mean I just found the book, and in my—”
I stopped at the look on his face.
The light from the gray window seemed to have aged him ten years.
“What do you mean, it is mine?”
Rossi slowly stood up and walked to a corner of his study behind his desk, and climbed two library stepladders.
He took down a small black book.
He stood there for a moment, gazing at it, as if reluctant to hand it over to me.
Then he did, and said, “What do you think of this?”
It was a small book bound in old brown velvet, like an old missal or breviary, with no writing on the spine or front, so I had no idea what kind of book it was.
It had a brass clasp that sprang open at a touch.
The book fell open in the middle to my—to what I called my—dragon.
This time, it covered the edges of the pages, its claws extended, its teeth bared, the heading still in the same Gothic letters, on the same little banner.
“Of course,” Rossi’s voice sounded in my ears.
“I had time, and I found the provenance of this illustration.
It is Central European in style, published circa 1512—so you see it can be moved around according to content, if there is any.”
I carefully turned the delicate pages.
There was no title on the pages preceding—yes, I knew that already.
“What a strange coincidence.”
“The back of the book has water stains on it, perhaps from a trip on the Black Sea.
Even the Smithsonian could not tell me what had happened on that trip.
You see, I even went to the trouble of having a chemical analysis done.
It cost me a full three hundred dollars to learn that the thing had been in some rocky, dusty environment, very likely for seventeen hundred years.
I even went all the way to Istanbul to trace its origin.
But strangest of all is how I acquired it.
He held out his hand, and I gladly returned the old, fragile book to him.
“Did you buy it somewhere?”
“I found it on my desk when I was a graduate student.”
A tremor went through me.
“On your desk?”
“On the desk in my carrel in the library, to be exact.”
“And where—where did it come from?
Was it a gift?”
“Perhaps.”
Rossi laughed strangely.
He seemed to be trying to control some emotion.
“Another cup of coffee?”
“Yes.
And now that I have found a companion for the book I gave you, you will know even better where it belongs, and they cannot be unrelated.”
“They cannot be unrelated.”
Even with the aroma of fresh coffee in the air, the voice sounded hollow.
“And your research?
Chemical analysis alone is not enough.
You said you had tried to learn more—?”
“I tried to learn more.”
He sat down, his small but seemingly solid hands cupping the coffee mug.
“I think I owe you more than a story,” he said calmly.
“Have you heard of Vlad Tepes—the Impaler?”
“Yes, Dracula.
Ruler of a territory in the Carpathian Mountains, also known as Béla Lugosi.”
“Yes—or one of them.
They were an old family before the most obnoxious member of their clan took power.
Did you look up his record when you went to the library?
You did, didn’t you?
A bad omen.
That afternoon, when I saw the strange book, I looked up the word—the name, and Transylvania, Wallachia, and the Carpathians.
I was immediately fascinated.
Let us talk about the Carpathians.
For historians, it has always been a mysterious region.
Of course, the basic story of Dracula has been mulled over many times, and there is not much to excavate.
He was the king of Wallachia, ruler in the fifteenth century, hated by the Ottoman Empire and by his own people.
He was considered the worst of all medieval tyrants.
Dracula means son of Dracul—or son of the dragon.
The Holy Roman Emperor Sigismund appointed his father the head of the “Order of the Dragon,” an organization to defend the Holy Roman Empire against the Ottoman Turks.

In fact, there is evidence that Dracula’s father handed over the young Dracula to the Turks as a hostage in a political negotiation, and that Dracula’s own brutality was partly due to his witnessing Ottoman tortures.
Rossi shook his head.
“In any case, Vlad was killed in a fight with the Turks, perhaps by his own men, and buried on a small island in Lake Snagov.
His memory became a legend, passed down from generation to generation by superstitious peasants.
At the end of the nineteenth century, an exaggerated writer—Bram Stoker—influenced by this, took the name Dracula and attached it to a character of his own invention, a vampire.
Vlad Tepes was terrifying in his cruelty, but he was not a vampire, of course.
Stoker’s book made no mention of Vlad, though his Dracula spoke of his family’s glorious history of fighting the Turks.
Rossi sighed.
“Stoker gathered legends about vampires in his book—and about Transylvania, though he had never visited there.
In fact, Vlad Dracula was the ruler of Wallachia, and Wallachia bordered Transylvania.
In the twentieth century, Hollywood continued to revive and perpetuate the myth of the vampire.
This is as much as I know, by the way.
I was speechless.
He sighed, as if unwilling to go on.
“You see, Vlad Dracula is still being researched in the great archives of Central and Eastern Europe, perhaps even in his homeland.
But he started out by killing Turks.
I found that no one had investigated the legend of Dracula in the history of the Ottoman Empire.
So I decided to go to Istanbul, as a bit of a holiday from my research into early Greek economics.
Oh, I published all my findings on Greek research, with a touch of vindictiveness.
He was silent for a while, gazing out the window.
“I think I should tell you my findings in Istanbul now, and then I will not think about it anymore.
You too, by the way, came into one of these beautiful books.”
He laid his hand solemnly on the two books stacked together.
“If I do not tell you, you may repeat my mistakes, and perhaps encounter greater danger.”
He smiled grimly at a spot above his desk.
“And I have saved you a lot of trouble writing grant proposals.”
I could not smile.
What was he implying?
I suddenly thought that I had underestimated my mentor’s peculiar sense of humor.
Perhaps this was a carefully staged prank—he had two of these dangerous antique books, had put one on my desk, knowing I would bring it to him, and I had done so like a fool.
But I saw his face suddenly turn ashen in the lamplight, his beard unshaven, his eyes vacant, his usual cheerfulness and humor gone.
I leaned toward him and asked, “What do you want to tell me?”
“Dracula—
He paused.
Dracula—Vlad Tepes—is still alive.”
“Good heavens,” my father said suddenly, glancing at his watch.
“Why didn’t you tell me?
It’s almost seven o’clock.”
I tucked my cold hands into the pockets of my navy-blue coat.
“I didn’t know,” I said.
“Please go on, don’t stop now.”
I felt that my father’s face seemed unreal for a moment.
I had never thought my father could possibly—I don’t know how to say it—be deranged?
Was he disoriented for a few minutes from telling that story?
“It’s too late, and the story is long.
My father picked up his teacup, then set it down.
I saw his hand tremble.
“Tell me more,” I said.
“If we don’t go now, they will come to fetch us.”
Night had fallen—a cold, foggy, damp East European night.
The streets were deserted, with hardly a pedestrian.
“Put on your hat,” my father said, always wearing one himself.
As we were about to pass under a rain-washed fig tree, he suddenly stopped, put his arm out, and shielded me, as if a car had just sped past us.
But there was no car, and the street was quiet under the yellow streetlamps, as if in the country.
My father looked cautiously from side to side.
I felt there was no one there, but my hat brim obscured some of my vision.
He stood still, and turned his head to listen intently, his body utterly still.
Then he exhaled heavily, and we walked on, discussing what we would have for dinner at the inn.
I never heard any more about Dracula on that trip.
I soon learned my father’s pattern of fear: he would tell me only small bits of the story at a time, not for dramatic effect, but to protect something—his strength? his sanity?
Back home in Amsterdam, my father was particularly reticent and busy.
I waited uneasily for an opportunity to ask him about Professor Rossi.
But he seemed to avoid me, unless I happened to sit down beside him, waiting for a pause in which to ask my question.
Then he would reach out and absentmindedly, though with a hint of sadness, stroke my hair.
At those times, I could not bring myself to ask about Professor Rossi’s story.
When my father went south again, he took me with him.
He had a meeting to attend, not a very formal one, not worth a special trip.
But he said he wanted to show me the country.

On the bus, I watched the scenery with rapt attention; the main street of Ragusa was paved with marble, so polished by the soles of so many feet over so many centuries, and the reflections from the lights of the shops and palaces around it, that it gleamed as if it were the surface of a great canal.
At the sea end of the city, we slumped at a coffee table, which had once been the center of town.
“The South is so pleasant,” my father said contentedly, picking up a bottle of whiskey and a plate of fried sardines.
“When were you here before?”
I was beginning to believe that my father had a past life, a life before I was born.
“I have been here several times, four or five.
The first time was many years ago, when I was a student.
My mentor suggested I come here from Italy, from Ragusa, to see the wonders.
I was studying—I told you, I spent one summer in Florence studying Italian.”
“You mean Professor Rossi.”
“Yes.”
My father gave me a quick glance, then looked back at his whiskey.
“I should tell you more about him.”
“I would like to hear,” I said carefully.
My father sighed.
“All right, I’ll tell you more about Rossi tomorrow, during the day, when I’m not too tired, and we can have some time to look at the walls.”
He gestured with his glass to the gray, bright walls above the hotel.
“It’s better to tell stories during the day, especially stories like that.”
“What do you mean by that?”
I asked him, stuttering slightly.
“I’ll say it again,” Rossi said emphatically.
“I discovered in Istanbul that Dracula is still among us.
Or at least he was when I was there.”
I stared at him, dumbfounded.
“I know you may think I’m mad,” he said kindly.
“I tell you that anyone who has spent enough time wrestling with history can go mad.”
He sighed.
“In Istanbul there is a little-known archive created by Sultan Mehmed II.
In it, I found some maps that showed the burial place of a man who massacred Turks, and I thought it might be Vlad Dracula.
There were three maps, all of the same region, but with different scales, and more detailed.
He tapped his strange book with his finger as he spoke.
“The text in the center of the third map is in a primitive Slavic dialect.
Only a scholar fluent in many languages can make sense of it.
I tried, but could not be sure.”
Rossi shook his head, as if still regretting his limited knowledge.
“One afternoon, I was studying the position of the evil tomb on the third and most puzzling map.
You remember that Vlad Tepes was buried in a monastery on an island in Lake Snagov, Romania.
This map, like the other two, did not show a lake island—though it did show a river that widened in the middle.
In the center of the map, above the evil tomb, wherever that may be, there was a crudely drawn dragon wearing a crown on its head, with a castle.
The dragon was slightly different from the one in my—in our—book, but I guessed it must have come to the Turks with the legend of Dracula.
Below the dragon, someone had written in very small letters.

At first I thought it was Arabic, but after looking at it closely with a magnifying glass, I suddenly realized that the letters were Greek, and I began to translate them aloud, breaking all the rules—though the library was empty except for me, and an occasional bored librarian who clearly wanted to see if I was stealing anything.
At that moment, I was alone.
The tiny letters danced before my eyes, and I read them aloud:
‘Here it cohabits with evil.
Reader, dig him up with a single word.’”
At this very moment, I heard a door slam in the lobby downstairs.
Heavy footsteps echoed in the stairwell.
The thought still spun in my mind: the magnifying glass told me this map was unlike the other two, it had been marked by three different people, in three different languages.
The handwriting and the languages were different.
The ink colors were different, old and ancient.
I suddenly had an idea—you know, the kind a scholar gets after long, diligent study.
I thought the map was originally the sketch in the center and the surrounding mountains, with the Greek incantation in the center.
Perhaps it was later marked with the Slavic dialect of the places it mentioned—at least in code.

Then it somehow fell into Ottoman hands, and proverbs from the Koran were added around it, encircling or imprisoning the evil prophecy in the middle, or warding it off with talismans, to resist the dark forces.
If this were true, then who was the first person who marked this map, perhaps even drew it, who knew Greek?
I knew that in Dracula’s time, Byzantine scholars used Greek, while Ottoman scholars mostly did not.
Before I could write down my thoughts, a tall, powerfully built man entered, strode past the books, and stopped opposite my desk.
He had the air of an intruder, and I was sure he was not a librarian, and I felt I should stand up, but out of pride I did not: it would have made me seem too deferential, and he an interloper, rude.
We looked into each other’s faces, and I have never been so surprised.
My own research was so arcane, and this man seemed so out of place.
He was handsome, his skin tanned, impeccably groomed.
He looked at me provocatively, and said in a low voice, with a Turkish accent, “Sir, I do not think you have the right to do this.”
“Do what?”
My academic vigilance immediately rose.
“This research.
The Turkish government believes the materials you have accessed are national private archives.
May I see your credentials?”
“Who are you?”
I asked equally calmly.
“May I see yours?”
He took a wallet from an inside pocket of his coat and snapped it open on the desk in front of me, then snapped it shut just as quickly.
“Ministry of Cultural Resources,” he said coldly.
“I know you have no real plan to communicate with the Turkish government about this research, do you?”
“Not exactly.”
I handed him a letter from the National Library stating that I had permission to use research materials in all branches of the Istanbul libraries.
“That is not enough,” he said, tossing it back onto my documents.
“Perhaps you will have to come with me.”
“Where?”
I stood up, feeling more secure.
But I still hoped he would not interpret my standing as submission.
“To the police station, if necessary.”
“Preposterous.”
I had learned to raise my voice when questioning bureaucracy.
“I am a doctoral candidate at Oxford University, a British citizen.
I contacted the university here as soon as I arrived in Istanbul and received this letter of recommendation.
I will not go to the police station to be questioned—or by you.”
“I see.”
He smiled, and it made me sick.
“Let me see what you are doing.
Please step aside.”
He picked up the map I had been studying, his hands suddenly becoming gentle, almost solicitous.
He looked at it as if he knew what it was without having to look closely.
But I thought he was bluffing.
“This is archive material, is it not?”
“Yes,” I said indignantly.
“This is valuable property of the Turkish government.
I’m sure you don’t need it in a foreign country.
Is this little piece of paper, this little map, what brought you from your university in England to Istanbul?”
I had considered refuting him, saying I had other work to do, and that he should not interfere with my research, but I immediately realized that this would invite more questions.
“Simply put, yes.”
“Simply put?”
He repeated, in an even softer tone.
“I think you will find this item temporarily confiscated.
It is an embarrassment for foreign researchers to see this.”
I was burning with rage.
I was so close to finding the answer.
Fortunately, I had not brought the map of the Carpathians I had carefully copied that morning, which I had intended to compare with the other one the next day.
I had hidden the copied map in my suitcase at the hotel.
“You have no right to confiscate material that I have been granted permission to study,” I ground out.
“I shall report this immediately to the National Library and the British Embassy.

They are obscure medieval materials.
I am sure they have no bearing on the interests of the Turkish government.”
The official shifted his gaze from me.
“It is for your own good,” he said impassively.
“It would be best to come back another time, with someone else to do this research.”
I backed away from the desk, thinking I had gone mad from these peculiar documents, that I was truly delirious.
But it was broad daylight, and everything was normal, including the man in the black wool suit, and his faint scent of long unwashed body, sweat, and something else beneath his cologne.
Nothing had suddenly disappeared or changed.
After a few seconds, he came back from his reverie, seemingly satisfied with what he saw—or what I saw—and smiled again.
“For your own good, Professor.”
I stood there, unable to utter a word.
He rolled the map in his hands and walked away, and I heard his footsteps fade on the stairwell.

“Excuse me,” I said to him, my voice caught in my throat.
“Excuse me, but that was really outrageous.”
He looked up, puzzled.
“Who was that? That official?”
“Official?”
The librarian repeated my word, his thick gray hair bobbing.
“The man from what ministry, the one who came up.
Wasn’t it you who let him up?”
He regarded me curiously.
“Someone came up? No one has entered for the past three hours.
I have been sitting by the entrance myself.
I’m afraid we don’t get many researchers here.”
“That man—” I said, and then stopped.
I suddenly found myself reduced to a mad foreigner making gestures.
He took my map, I mean the archive map.
“The map, Professor?”
“I was studying a map.
I borrowed it from the front desk this morning.”
“Not that map?”
He pointed to my desk, where a plain map of the Balkans lay, one I had never seen in my life.
It had definitely not been there five minutes before.
The librarian went to put down his second volume.
“It’s all right.”
I gathered my books as quickly as I could and left the library.
There was no sign of the official on the busy street, though I saw several men in similar suits hurrying past me with briefcases.
I returned to my hotel room, and found that my luggage had been moved due to some practical problem with the room.
The old maps I had copied and my notes that I had not needed to take with me that morning were gone.
My suitcase had been disturbed, and then neatly repacked.
The hotel had no knowledge of the incident.
I didn’t sleep all night, listening for every sound outside.
The next morning, I packed my unwashed clothes and a few dictionaries and took the ferry back to Greece.
Back home in Amsterdam, my father was particularly reticent and busy.
I waited uneasily for an opportunity to ask him about Professor Rossi.
But he seemed to avoid me, unless I happened to sit down beside him, waiting for a pause in which to ask my question.
Then he would reach out and absentmindedly, though with a hint of sadness, stroke my hair.
At those times, I could not bring myself to ask about Professor Rossi’s story.
When my father went south again, he took me with him.
He had a meeting to attend, not a very formal one, not worth a special trip.
But he said he wanted to show me the country.

On the bus, I watched the scenery with rapt attention; the main street of Ragusa was paved with marble, so polished by the soles of so many feet over so many centuries, and the reflections from the lights of the shops and palaces around it, that it gleamed as if it were the surface of a great canal.
At the sea end of the city, we slumped at a coffee table, which had once been the center of town.
“The South is so pleasant,” my father said contentedly, picking up a bottle of whiskey and a plate of fried sardines.
“When were you here before?”
I was beginning to believe that my father had a past life, a life before I was born.
“I have been here several times, four or five.
The first time was many years ago, when I was a student.
My mentor suggested I come here from Italy, from Ragusa, to see the wonders.
I was studying—I told you, I spent one summer in Florence studying Italian.”
“You mean Professor Rossi.”
“Yes.”
My father gave me a quick glance, then looked back at his whiskey.
“I should tell you more about him.”
“I would like to hear,” I said carefully.
My father sighed.

He gestured with his glass to the gray, bright walls above the hotel.
“It’s better to tell stories during the day, especially stories like that.”
“What do you mean by that?”
I asked him, stuttering slightly.
“I’ll say it again,” Rossi said emphatically.
“I discovered in Istanbul that Dracula is still among us.
Or at least he was when I was there.”
I stared at him, dumbfounded.
“I know you may think I’m mad,” he said kindly.
“I tell you that anyone who has spent enough time wrestling with history can go mad.”
He sighed.
“In Istanbul there is a little-known archive created by Sultan Mehmed II.
In it, I found some maps that showed the burial place of a man who massacred Turks, and I thought it might be Vlad Dracula.
There were three maps, all of the same region, but with different scales, and more detailed.
He tapped his strange book with his finger as he spoke.
“The text in the center of the third map is in a primitive Slavic dialect.
Only a scholar fluent in many languages can make sense of it.
I tried, but could not be sure.”
Rossi shook his head, as if still regretting his limited knowledge.
“One afternoon, I was studying the position of the evil tomb on the third and most puzzling map.
You remember that Vlad Tepes was buried in a monastery on an island in Lake Snagov, Romania.
This map, like the other two, did not show a lake island—though it did show a river that widened in the middle.
In the center of the map, above the evil tomb, wherever that may be, there was a crudely drawn dragon wearing a crown on its head, with a castle.
The dragon was slightly different from the one in my—in our—book, but I guessed it must have come to the Turks with the legend of Dracula.
Below the dragon, someone had written in very small letters.

At first I thought it was Arabic, but after looking at it closely with a magnifying glass, I suddenly realized that the letters were Greek, and I began to translate them aloud, breaking all the rules—though the library was empty except for me, and an occasional bored librarian who clearly wanted to see if I was stealing anything.
At that moment, I was alone.
The tiny letters danced before my eyes, and I read them aloud:
‘Here it cohabits with evil.
Reader, dig him up with a single word.’”
At this very moment, I heard a door slam in the lobby downstairs.
Heavy footsteps echoed in the stairwell.
The thought still spun in my mind: the magnifying glass told me this map was unlike the other two, it had been marked by three different people, in three different languages.
The handwriting and the languages were different.
The ink colors were different, old and ancient.
I suddenly had an idea—you know, the kind a scholar gets after long, diligent study.
I thought the map was originally the sketch in the center and the surrounding mountains, with the Greek incantation in the center.
Perhaps it was later marked with the Slavic dialect of the places it mentioned—at least in code.

Then it somehow fell into Ottoman hands, and proverbs from the Koran were added around it, encircling or imprisoning the evil prophecy in the middle, or warding it off with talismans, to resist the dark forces.
If this were true, then who was the first person who marked this map, perhaps even drew it, who knew Greek?
I knew that in Dracula’s time, Byzantine scholars used Greek, while Ottoman scholars mostly did not.
Before I could write down my thoughts, a tall, powerfully built man entered, strode past the books, and stopped opposite my desk.
He had the air of an intruder, and I was sure he was not a librarian, and I felt I should stand up, but out of pride I did not: it would have made me seem too deferential, and he an interloper, rude.
We looked into each other’s faces, and I have never been so surprised.
My own research was so arcane, and this man seemed so out of place.
He was handsome, his skin tanned, impeccably groomed.
He looked at me provocatively, and said in a low voice, with a Turkish accent, “Sir, I do not think you have the right to do this.”
“Do what?”
My academic vigilance immediately rose.
“This research.
The Turkish government believes the materials you have accessed are national private archives.
May I see your credentials?”
“Who are you?”
I asked equally calmly.
“May I see yours?”
He took a wallet from an inside pocket of his coat and snapped it open on the desk in front of me, then snapped it shut just as quickly.
“Ministry of Cultural Resources,” he said coldly.
“I know you have no real plan to communicate with the Turkish government about this research, do you?”
“Not exactly.”
I handed him a letter from the National Library stating that I had permission to use research materials in all branches of the Istanbul libraries.
“That is not enough,” he said, tossing it back onto my documents.
“Perhaps you will have to come with me.”
“Where?”
I stood up, feeling more secure.
But I still hoped he would not interpret my standing as submission.
“To the police station, if necessary.”
“Preposterous.”
I had learned to raise my voice when questioning bureaucracy.
“I am a doctoral candidate at Oxford University, a British citizen.
I contacted the university here as soon as I arrived in Istanbul and received this letter of recommendation.
I will not go to the police station to be questioned—or by you.”
“I see.”
He smiled, and it made me sick.
“Let me see what you are doing.
Please step aside.”
He picked up the map I had been studying, his hands suddenly becoming gentle, almost solicitous.
He looked at it as if he knew what it was without having to look closely.
But I thought he was bluffing.
“This is archive material, is it not?”
“Yes,” I said indignantly.
“This is valuable property of the Turkish government.
I’m sure you don’t need it in a foreign country.
Is this little piece of paper, this little map, what brought you from your university in England to Istanbul?”
I had considered refuting him, saying I had other work to do, and that he should not interfere with my research, but I immediately realized that this would invite more questions.
